title: Tiger Woods recovers from awful start to make stunning comeback in his first tournament since knee surgery
text:
As if 2019 was not to be remembered as the year of the Tiger Woods comeback anyway, the 15-time major winner set out on Thursday to make sure with a stunning turnaround in his first tournament in nine weeks following his latest knee operation.

Woods bogeyed the first three holes of the Zozo Championship, the first PGA Tour event ever held in Japan, and wise sages were nodding to each other that he was clearly suffering from rust and faced another mountain to climb before the game would again witness the form that took him to his extraordinary victory at the Masters in April.

But Woods, 43, rarely obeys the script and, in front of huge and vocal Tokyo crowds, proceeded to shrug off that 5-5-5 beginning and play the remaining 15 holes in nine-under. It was a staggering run considering the fact that players of the calibre of Rory Mcilroy - who shot a three-over 73 - struggled to make any headway on the Narashino Country Club.

On six-under after his 64, Woods is sharing the lead with countryman Gary Woodland and is the favourite to win his 82nd PGA Tour crown, so tying Sam Snead’s record. Woods believes his fifth knee surgery - which repaired cartilage damage - was a huge success, removing the pain that bothered him for a year to such an extent that he overcompensated in his swing, leading to further back issues.
description: As if 2019 was not to be remembered as the year of the Tiger Woods comeback anyway, the 15-time major winner set out on Thursday to make sure with a stunning turnaround in his first tournament in nine weeks following his latest knee operation.
